jcr:content.jcr:title: Transport in the United Arab Emirates

contentheadline.headline: Transport in the United Arab Emirates

contentrichtext.text: {{Life in the United Arab Emirates}} {{essay-like|date=January 2013}} ==Private vehicles== Private vehicles are commonly used. Driving licenses are available to those of at least 18 years. Women are allowed to drive. An extensive and modern road network connects the main coastal cities; the desert is less developed ==Buses== Buses are provided by the country not by any one person. ==Air transport== The UAE has well-developed air travel infrastructure. The [[General Civil Aviation Authority]](GCAA) started applying an advanced program in 2010 that allows the assessment of aircraft registered in foreign countries in order to ensure their safety and airworthiness.<ref>http://www.arabiansupplychain.com/article-3702-breaking-news-uae-bans-antonov-an-12-aircraft/#.UcaD7BZCWxI</ref> In 2011 it banned all aircraft registered in countries like [[Congo DR]], [[Swaziland]], [[Equatorial Guinea]], [[Sierra Leone]] and [[São Tomé and Príncipe]] due to their poor safety standards.<ref>{{cite web| title =United Arab Emirates bans Congo registered aircraft| publisher =eTN| url =http://www.eturbonews.com/14630/united-arab-emirates-bans-congo-registered-aircraft| accessdate = 22 March 2011}}</ref> ===Airports=== {{main|List of airports in the United Arab Emirates}} There are 42 airports spread across the UAE as of 2012.<ref>https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ae.html Airports in UAE- CIA Factbook</ref> '''Airports with paved runways''' <br>''total:'' 25 <br>''over 3,047 m:'' 12 <br>''2,438 to 3,047 m:'' 3 <br>''1,524 to 2,437 m:'' 4 <br>''914 to 1,523 m:'' 4 <br>''under 914 m:'' 2 '''Airports with unpaved runways''' <br>''total:'' 17 <br>''over 3,047 m:'' 1 <br>''2,438 to 3,047 m:'' 1 <br>''1,524 to 2,437 m:'' 4 <br>''914 to 1,523 m:'' 6 <br>''under 914 m:'' 5 '''Heliports''' 5 are known as of 2012 ===Airlines=== {{main|List of airlines of the United Arab Emirates}} [[Etihad Airways]] is the National Airline of the UAE. ==Rail== {{main|Rail transport in the United Arab Emirates}} * Rail does not play a large part in transport in UAE but investment in rail is expected to continue ==Incidents== Six people were killed, at least 40 were injured and dozens of vehicles burned March 11, 2008 when hundreds of cars collided on a fog-shrouded [[Abu Dhabi - Dubai]] highway.<ref>[http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/meast/03/11/emirates.wreck/index.html Incidents]</ref> ==Pipelines== [[Crude oil]] {{convert|830|km|mi|0}}; [[natural gas]], including natural gas liquids, {{convert|870|km|mi|0}} ==Ports and harbors== [[Ajman]] Port, [[Fujairah]] Port, [[Das Island]], [[Khalifa Port]], [[Mina' Zayid]] and Mina Jabal Al Dhanna in [[Abu Dhabi]], [[Khawr Fakkan]], Mina Al Hemreya and, [[Mina' Khalid]] in [[Sharjah (city)|Sharjah]], [[Mina' Jabal 'Ali]], [[Port Rashid]] in Dubai, [[Mina' Saqr]] in [[Ras Al Khaimah]], [[Umm al-Qaiwain]] Port, ==Merchant marine== <br>''total:'' 68 ships (1,000 GRT or over) totaling 1,107,442 GRT/{{DWT|1,795,235|metric|first=yes}} <br>''ships by type:'' bulk 1, cargo 18, chemical tanker 3, container 8, liquified gas 1, livestock carrier 1, passenger 1, petroleum tanker 27, [[roll-on/roll-off]] 7, specialized tanker 1 (1999 est.) ==See also== * [[United Arab Emirates]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{United Arab Emirates topics}} {{Asia topic|Transport in}} {{Asia in topic|Rail transport in}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Transportation In The United Arab Emirates}} [[Category:Transport in the United Arab Emirates|*]]
